æ™‰å”å”è™è€…ï¼Œå‘¨æ­¦ç‹å­è€Œæˆç‹å¼Ÿã€‚ åˆï¼Œæ­¦ç‹èˆ‡å”è™æ¯æœƒæ™‚ï¼Œå¤¢å¤©è¬‚æ­¦ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œä½™å‘½å¥³ç”Ÿå­ï¼Œåè™ï¼Œä½™èˆ‡ä¹‹å”ã€‚ã€ åŠç”Ÿå­ï¼Œæ–‡åœ¨å…¶æ‰‹æ›°ã€Œè™ã€ï¼Œæ•…é‚å› å‘½ä¹‹æ›°è™ã€‚
Tang Shu Yu of Jin was the son of King Wu of Zhou and younger brother of King Cheng. Once, when King Wu's wife was pregnant with Shu Yu, she dreamed that Heaven told King Wu: 'I command you to give birth to a son named Yu, and I grant him Tang.' When the child was born, the character 'Yu' was written on his hand, so they named him Yu as the dream had commanded.
2
æ­¦ç‹å´©ï¼Œæˆç‹ç«‹ï¼Œå”æœ‰äº‚ï¼Œå‘¨å…¬èª…æ»…å”ã€‚ æˆç‹èˆ‡å”è™æˆ²ï¼Œå‰Šæ¡è‘‰ç‚ºçªä»¥èˆ‡å”è™ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œä»¥æ­¤å°è‹¥ã€‚ã€ å²ä½šå› è«‹æ“‡æ—¥ç«‹å”è™ã€‚ æˆç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾èˆ‡ä¹‹æˆ²è€³ã€‚ã€ å²ä½šæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤©å­ç„¡æˆ²è¨€ã€‚ è¨€å‰‡å²æ›¸ä¹‹ï¼Œç¦®æˆä¹‹ï¼Œæ¨‚æ­Œä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯é‚å°å”è™æ–¼å”ã€‚ å”åœ¨æ²³ã€æ±¾ä¹‹æ±ï¼Œæ–¹ç™¾é‡Œï¼Œæ•…æ›°å”å”è™ã€‚ å§“å§¬æ°ï¼Œå­—å­äºã€‚
When King Wu died and King Cheng ascended the throne, Tang rebelled, so the Duke of Zhou executed and extinguished the Tang state. King Cheng was playing with Shu Yu and cut a paulownia leaf into the shape of a jade tablet, saying: 'With this I enfeoff you.' Shi Yi therefore requested that they choose an auspicious day to establish Shu Yu as ruler. King Cheng said: 'I was only playing with him.' Shi Yi replied: 'The Son of Heaven does not make frivolous statements. Whatever he says gets recorded by the historians, formalized by ritual, and celebrated in music.' Thus Shu Yu was enfeoffed at Tang. Tang was located east of the Yellow River and Fen River, covering a square area of one hundred li, which is why he was called Tang Shu Yu. He belonged to the Ji clan and was styled Zi Yu.
3
å”å”å­ç‡®ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ™‰ä¾¯ã€‚ æ™‰ä¾¯å­å¯§æ—ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ­¦ä¾¯ã€‚ æ­¦ä¾¯ä¹‹å­æœäººï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæˆä¾¯ã€‚ æˆä¾¯å­ç¦ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºå²ä¾¯ã€‚ å²ä¾¯ä¹‹å­å®œè‡¼ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºé–ä¾¯ã€‚ é–ä¾¯å·²ä¾†ï¼Œå¹´ç´€å¯æ¨ã€‚ è‡ªå”å”è‡³é–ä¾¯äº”ä¸–ï¼Œç„¡å…¶å¹´æ•¸ã€‚
Tang Shu's son was Xie, who became the Marquis of Jin. The Marquis of Jin's son was Ning Zu, who became Marquis Wu. Marquis Wu's son was Fu Ren, who became Marquis Cheng. Marquis Cheng's son was Fu, who became Marquis Li. Marquis Li's son was Yi Jiu, who became Marquis Jing. From Marquis Jing onward, the chronology can be reconstructed. From Tang Shu to Marquis Jing was five generations, but no specific years are recorded for them.
4
é–ä¾¯åä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œå‘¨å²ç‹è¿·æƒ‘æš´è™ï¼Œåœ‹äººä½œäº‚ï¼Œå²ç‹å‡ºå¥”äºå½˜ï¼Œå¤§è‡£è¡Œæ”¿ï¼Œæ•…æ›°ã€Œå…±å’Œã€ã€‚
In the seventeenth year of Marquis Jing's reign, King Li of Zhou was confused and tyrannical, so the people rose up in rebellion, King Li fled to Zhi, and the ministers administered the government, which was called the 'Republican' period.
5
åå…«å¹´ï¼Œé–ä¾¯å’ï¼Œå­é‡ä¾¯å¸å¾’ç«‹ã€‚ é‡ä¾¯åå››å¹´ï¼Œå‘¨å®£ç‹åˆç«‹ã€‚ åå…«å¹´ï¼Œé‡ä¾¯å’ï¼Œå­ç»ä¾¯ç±ç«‹ã€‚ ç»ä¾¯åä¸€å¹´å’ï¼Œå­ç©†ä¾¯è²»ç‹ç«‹ã€‚
In the eighteenth year, Marquis Jing died, and his son Xi Hou Si Tu ascended the throne. In the fourteenth year of Xi Hou's reign, King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne. In the eighteenth year, Xi Hou died, and his son Xian Hou Ji ascended the throne. In the eleventh year, Xian Hou died, and his son Mu Hou Fei Wang ascended the throne.
6
ç©†ä¾¯å››å¹´ï¼Œå–é½Šå¥³å§œæ°ç‚ºå¤«äººã€‚ ä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œä¼æ¢ã€‚ ç”Ÿå¤ªå­ä»‡ã€‚ åå¹´ï¼Œä¼åƒç•ï¼Œæœ‰åŠŸã€‚ ç”Ÿå°‘å­ï¼Œåæ›°æˆå¸«ã€‚ æ™‰äººå¸«æœæ›°ï¼šã€Œç•°å“‰ï¼Œå›ä¹‹å‘½å­ä¹Ÿï¼ å¤ªå­æ›°ä»‡ï¼Œä»‡è€…è®ä¹Ÿã€‚ å°‘å­æ›°æˆå¸«ï¼Œæˆå¸«å¤§è™Ÿï¼Œæˆä¹‹è€…ä¹Ÿã€‚ åè‡ªå‘½ä¹Ÿï¼› ç‰©è‡ªå®šä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šé©åº¶ååé€†ï¼Œæ­¤å¾Œæ™‰å…¶èƒ½æ¯‹äº‚ä¹ï¼Ÿã€
In the fourth year of Mu Hou's reign, he took a daughter of the Jiang clan from Qi as his wife. In the seventh year, he attacked the state of Tiao. He fathered the crown prince Qiu. In the tenth year, he attacked Qian Mu and achieved merit. He fathered a younger son named Cheng Shi. The Jin official Shi Fu said: 'How ominous! The lord names his sons this way! The crown prince is named Qiu, which means enemy. The younger son is named Cheng Shi, which means one who completes it - a great title. Names are self-fulfilling prophecies; things determine their own nature. Now the legitimate and illegitimate sons have names that contradict each other - this bodes ill for Jin's future, for there will surely be no peace.'
7
äºŒåä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œç©†ä¾¯å’ï¼Œå¼Ÿæ®¤å”è‡ªç«‹ï¼Œå¤ªå­ä»‡å‡ºå¥”ã€‚ æ®¤å”ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œå‘¨å®£ç‹å´©ã€‚ å››å¹´ï¼Œç©†ä¾¯å¤ªå­ä»‡ç‡å…¶å¾’è¥²æ®¤å”è€Œç«‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ–‡ä¾¯ã€‚
In the twenty-seventh year, Mu Hou died, and his younger brother Shang Shu usurped the throne, while Crown Prince Qiu fled into exile. In the third year of Shang Shu's reign, King Xuan of Zhou died. In the fourth year, Mu Hou's Crown Prince Qiu led his followers, attacked Shang Shu, and ascended the throne as Wen Hou.
8
æ–‡ä¾¯åå¹´ï¼Œå‘¨å¹½ç‹ç„¡é“ï¼ŒçŠ¬æˆæ®ºå¹½ç‹ï¼Œå‘¨æ±å¾™ã€‚ è€Œç§¦è¥„å…¬å§‹åˆ—ç‚ºè«¸ä¾¯ã€‚
In the tenth year of Wen Hou's reign, King You of Zhou was without virtue, the Quanrong killed King You, and Zhou moved eastward. Qin Xiang Gong began to be ranked among the feudal lords.
9
ä¸‰åäº”å¹´ï¼Œæ–‡ä¾¯ä»‡å’ï¼Œå­æ˜­ä¾¯ä¼¯ç«‹ã€‚
In the thirty-fifth year, Wen Hou Qiu died, and his son Zhao Hou Bo ascended the throne.
10
æ˜­ä¾¯å…ƒå¹´ï¼Œå°æ–‡ä¾¯å¼Ÿæˆå¸«äºæ›²æ²ƒã€‚ æ›²æ²ƒé‚‘å¤§æ–¼ç¿¼ã€‚ ç¿¼ï¼Œæ™‰å›éƒ½é‚‘ä¹Ÿã€‚ æˆå¸«å°æ›²æ²ƒï¼Œè™Ÿç‚ºæ¡“å”ã€‚ é–ä¾¯åº¶å­«æ¬’è³“ç›¸æ¡“å”ã€‚ æ¡“å”æ˜¯æ™‚å¹´äº”åå…«çŸ£ï¼Œå¥½å¾·ï¼Œæ™‰åœ‹ä¹‹çœ¾çš†é™„ç„‰ã€‚ å›å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ™‰ä¹‹äº‚å…¶åœ¨æ›²æ²ƒçŸ£ã€‚ æœ«å¤§æ–¼æœ¬è€Œå¾—æ°‘å¿ƒï¼Œä¸äº‚ä½•å¾…ï¼ã€
In the first year of Zhao Hou's reign, he enfeoffed Wen Hou's younger brother Cheng Shi at Quwo. The city of Quwo was larger than Yi. Yi was the capital city of the Jin lord. Cheng Shi was enfeoffed at Quwo with the title of Huan Shu. Jing Hou's concubine-born grandson Luan Bin assisted Huan Shu. At this time, Huan Shu was fifty-eight years old, virtuous in nature, and all the people of Jin attached themselves to him. The gentleman said: 'The disorder in Jin will arise from Quwo. When the branch becomes larger than the root and wins the people's hearts, disorder is inevitable.'
11
ä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œæ™‰å¤§è‡£æ½˜çˆ¶å¼’å…¶å›æ˜­ä¾¯è€Œè¿æ›²æ²ƒæ¡“å”ã€‚ æ¡“å”æ¬²å…¥æ™‰ï¼Œæ™‰äººç™¼å…µæ”»æ¡“å”ã€‚ æ¡“å”æ•—ï¼Œé‚„æ­¸æ›²æ²ƒã€‚ æ™‰äººå…±ç«‹æ˜­ä¾¯å­å¹³ç‚ºå›ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºå­ä¾¯ã€‚ èª…æ½˜çˆ¶ã€‚
In the seventh year, the Jin minister Pan Fu assassinated his lord Zhao Hou and welcomed Huan Shu of Quwo. Huan Shu wished to enter Jin, so the Jin people sent troops to attack him. Huan Shu was defeated and returned to Quwo. The Jin people together established Zhao Hou's son Ping as lord, who was called Xiao Hou. They executed Pan Fu.
12
å­ä¾¯å…«å¹´ï¼Œæ›²æ²ƒæ¡“å”å’ï¼Œå­èƒ›æ¡“å”ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ›²æ²ƒèŠä¼¯ã€‚ å­ä¾¯åäº”å¹´ï¼Œæ›²æ²ƒèŠä¼¯å¼’å…¶å›æ™‰å­ä¾¯äºç¿¼ã€‚ æ™‰äººæ”»æ›²æ²ƒèŠä¼¯ï¼ŒèŠä¼¯å¾©å…¥æ›²æ²ƒã€‚ æ™‰äººå¾©ç«‹å­ä¾¯å­éƒ„ç‚ºå›ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºé„‚ä¾¯ã€‚
In Xiao Hou's eighth year, Huan Shu of Quwo died, and his son Jia succeeded him as Huan Shu, who was called Zhuang Bo of Quwo. In Xiao Hou's fifteenth year, Zhuang Bo of Quwo assassinated his lord Xiao Hou of Jin at Yi. The Jin people attacked Zhuang Bo of Quwo, but Zhuang Bo retreated back into Quwo. The Jin people again established Xiao Hou's son Xi as lord, who was called E Hou.
13
é„‚ä¾¯å…­å¹´å’ã€‚ æ›²æ²ƒèŠä¼¯èæ™‰é„‚ä¾¯å’ï¼Œä¹ƒèˆˆå…µä¼æ™‰ã€‚ å‘¨å¹³ç‹ä½¿è™¢å…¬å°‡å…µä¼æ›²æ²ƒèŠä¼¯ï¼ŒèŠä¼¯èµ°ä¿æ›²æ²ƒã€‚ æ™‰äººå…±ç«‹é„‚ä¾¯å­å…‰ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºå“€ä¾¯ã€‚
E Hou died in his sixth year. When E Hou died, Zhuang Bo of Quwo raised troops and attacked Jin. King Ping of Zhou sent the Marquis of Guo to lead troops against Zhuang Bo of Quwo, but Zhuang Bo fled and defended Quwo. The Jin people together established E Hou's son Guang as lord, who was called Ai Hou.
14
å“€ä¾¯äºŒå¹´æ›²æ²ƒèŠä¼¯å’ï¼Œå­ç¨±ä»£èŠä¼¯ç«‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ›²æ²ƒæ­¦å…¬ã€‚ å“€ä¾¯å…­å¹´ï¼Œé­¯å¼’å…¶å›éš±å…¬ã€‚ å“€ä¾¯å…«å¹´ï¼Œæ™‰ä¾µé™˜å»·ã€‚ é™˜å»·èˆ‡æ›²æ²ƒæ­¦å…¬è¬€ï¼Œä¹å¹´ï¼Œä¼æ™‰äºæ±¾æ—ï¼Œè™œå“€ä¾¯ã€‚ æ™‰äººä¹ƒç«‹å“€ä¾¯å­å°å­ç‚ºå›ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºå°å­ä¾¯ã€‚
In Ai Hou's second year, Zhuang Bo of Quwo died, and his son Cheng succeeded him as Wu Gong of Quwo. In Ai Hou's sixth year, Lu assassinated its lord Duke Yin. In Ai Hou's eighth year, Jin invaded Xing Ting. Xing Ting plotted with Wu Gong of Quwo, and in the ninth year they attacked Jin at the Fen River crossing, capturing Ai Hou. The Jin people then established Ai Hou's son Xiao Zi as lord, who was called Xiao Zi Hou.
15
å°å­å…ƒå¹´ï¼Œæ›²æ²ƒæ­¦å…¬ä½¿éŸ“è¬æ®ºæ‰€è™œæ™‰å“€ä¾¯ã€‚ æ›²æ²ƒç›Šå½Šï¼Œæ™‰ç„¡å¦‚ä¹‹ä½•ã€‚
In Xiao Zi Hou's first year, Wu Gong of Quwo sent Han Wan to kill the captive Ai Hou. Quwo grew increasingly strong, and Jin could do nothing about it.
16
æ™‰å°å­ä¹‹å››å¹´ï¼Œæ›²æ²ƒæ­¦å…¬èª˜å¬æ™‰å°å­æ®ºä¹‹ã€‚ å‘¨æ¡“ç‹ä½¿è™¢ä»²ä¼æ›²æ²ƒæ­¦å…¬ï¼Œæ­¦å…¬å…¥äºæ›²æ²ƒï¼Œä¹ƒç«‹æ™‰å“€ä¾¯å¼Ÿç·¡ç‚ºæ™‰ä¾¯ã€‚
In Xiao Zi Hou's fourth year, Wu Gong of Quwo lured and summoned Xiao Zi Hou, then killed him. King Huan of Zhou sent Guo Zhong to attack Wu Gong of Quwo, but Wu Gong entered Quwo, so they established Jin Ai Hou's younger brother Min as the Jin lord.
17
æ™‰ä¾¯ç·¡å››å¹´ï¼Œå®‹åŸ·é„­ç¥­ä»²è€Œç«‹çªç‚ºé„­å›ã€‚ æ™‰ä¾¯åä¹å¹´ï¼Œé½Šäººç®¡è‡³çˆ¶å¼’å…¶å›è¥„å…¬ã€‚
In Jin Hou Min's fourth year, Song seized Ji Zhong of Zheng and established Tu as lord of Zheng. In Jin Hou Min's nineteenth year, Guan Zhi Fu of Qi assassinated his lord Duke Xiang.
18
æ™‰ä¾¯äºŒåå…«å¹´ï¼Œé½Šæ¡“å…¬å§‹éœ¸ã€‚ æ›²æ²ƒæ­¦å…¬ä¼æ™‰ä¾¯ç·¡ï¼Œæ»…ä¹‹ï¼Œç›¡ä»¥å…¶å¯¶å™¨è³‚ç»äºå‘¨é‡ç‹ã€‚ é‡ç‹å‘½æ›²æ²ƒæ­¦å…¬ç‚ºæ™‰å›ï¼Œåˆ—ç‚ºè«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œæ–¼æ˜¯ç›¡ä½µæ™‰åœ°è€Œæœ‰ä¹‹ã€‚
In Jin Hou Min's twenty-eighth year, Duke Huan of Qi became hegemon. Wu Gong of Quwo attacked Jin Hou Min, extinguished him, and completely bribed King Xi of Zhou with all his precious vessels. King Xi commanded Wu Gong of Quwo to become lord of Jin and be ranked among the feudal lords.
19
æ›²æ²ƒæ­¦å…¬å·²å³ä½ä¸‰åä¸ƒå¹´çŸ£ï¼Œæ›´è™Ÿæ›°æ™‰æ­¦å…¬ã€‚ æ™‰æ­¦å…¬å§‹éƒ½æ™‰åœ‹ï¼Œå‰å³ä½æ›²æ²ƒï¼Œé€šå¹´ä¸‰åå…«å¹´ã€‚
Wu Gong of Quwo had already been on the throne for thirty-seven years, but changed his title to Wu Gong of Jin. Wu Gong of Jin made Jiang his capital, though he had originally ascended at Quwo, and the total years came to thirty-eight.
20
æ­¦å…¬ç¨±è€…ï¼Œå…ˆæ™‰ç©†ä¾¯æ›¾å­«ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ›²æ²ƒæ¡“å”å­«ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ¡“å”è€…ï¼Œå§‹å°æ›²æ²ƒã€‚ æ­¦å…¬ï¼ŒèŠä¼¯å­ä¹Ÿã€‚ è‡ªæ¡“å”åˆå°æ›²æ²ƒä»¥è‡³æ­¦å…¬æ»…æ™‰ä¹Ÿï¼Œå‡¡å…­åä¸ƒæ­²ï¼Œè€Œå’ä»£æ™‰ç‚ºè«¸ä¾¯ã€‚ æ­¦å…¬ä»£æ™‰äºŒæ­²ï¼Œå’ã€‚ èˆ‡æ›²æ²ƒé€šå¹´ï¼Œå³ä½å‡¡ä¸‰åä¹å¹´è€Œå’ã€‚ å­ç»å…¬è©­è«¸ç«‹ã€‚
Wu Gong surnamed this: he was the great-grandson of Jin Mu Hou, and grandson of Huan Shu. Huan Shu was the first to be enfeoffed at Quwo. Wu Gong was Zhuang Bo's son. From Huan Shu's first enfeoffment at Quwo until Wu Gong extinguished Jin, sixty-seven years passed, and finally he replaced Jin to become a feudal lord. Wu Gong replaced Jin after two years, then died. Counting the years at Quwo, he had reigned thirty-nine years in total when he died. His son Xian Gong Gui Zhu succeeded him.

ç»å…¬å…ƒå¹´ï¼Œå‘¨æƒ ç‹å¼Ÿç©¨æ”»æƒ ç‹ï¼Œæƒ ç‹å‡ºå¥”ï¼Œå±…é„­ä¹‹æ«Ÿé‚‘ã€‚
In Xian Gong's first year, King Hui of Zhou's younger brother attacked King Hui, who fled and resided in the Li district of Zheng.

äº”å¹´ï¼Œä¼é©ªæˆï¼Œå¾—é©ªå§¬ã€é©ªå§¬å¼Ÿï¼Œä¿±æ„›å¹¸ä¹‹ã€‚
In the fifth year, he attacked the Lirong and obtained Li Ji and her younger brother, both of whom he loved and favored.
23
å…«å¹´ï¼Œå£«è’èªªå…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ•…æ™‰ä¹‹ç¾¤å…¬å­å¤šï¼Œä¸èª…ï¼Œäº‚ä¸”èµ·ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒä½¿ç›¡æ®ºè«¸å…¬å­ï¼Œè€ŒåŸèšéƒ½ä¹‹ï¼Œå‘½æ›°çµ³ï¼Œå§‹éƒ½çµ³ã€‚ ä¹å¹´ï¼Œæ™‰ç¾¤å…¬å­æ—¢äº¡å¥”è™¢ï¼Œè™¢ä»¥å…¶æ•…å†ä¼æ™‰ï¼Œå¼—å…‹ã€‚ åå¹´ï¼Œæ™‰æ¬²ä¼è™¢ï¼Œå£«è’æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸”å¾…å…¶äº‚ã€‚ã€
In the eighth year, Shi Kui advised the duke: 'The former duke had many sons from the various houses, but if they are not eliminated, disorder will surely arise.' Therefore he had all the various princes killed, walled and gathered Jiang as the capital, and named it Jiang, beginning to make Jiang his capital. In the ninth year, the various Jin princes had fled and taken refuge in Guo, so Guo attacked Jin twice on their account, but was unsuccessful. In the tenth year, Jin wished to attack Guo, but Shi Kui said: 'Wait for their internal disorder.'
24
åäºŒå¹´ï¼Œé©ªå§¬ç”Ÿå¥šé½Šã€‚ ç»å…¬æœ‰æ„å»¢å¤ªå­ï¼Œä¹ƒæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ›²æ²ƒå¾å…ˆç¥–å®—å»Ÿæ‰€åœ¨ï¼Œè€Œè’²é‚Šç§¦ï¼Œå±ˆé‚Šç¿Ÿï¼Œä¸ä½¿è«¸å­å±…ä¹‹ï¼Œæˆ‘æ‡¼ç„‰ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ä½¿å¤ªå­ç”³ç”Ÿå±…æ›²æ²ƒï¼Œå…¬å­é‡è€³å±…è’²ï¼Œå…¬å­å¤·å¾å±…å±ˆã€‚ ç»å…¬èˆ‡é©ªå§¬å­å¥šé½Šå±…çµ³ã€‚ æ™‰åœ‹ä»¥æ­¤çŸ¥å¤ªå­ä¸ç«‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤ªå­ç”³ç”Ÿï¼Œå…¶æ¯é½Šæ¡“å…¬å¥³ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ›°é½Šå§œï¼Œæ—©æ­»ã€‚ ç”³ç”ŸåŒæ¯å¥³å¼Ÿç‚ºç§¦ç©†å…¬å¤«äººã€‚ é‡è€³æ¯ï¼Œç¿Ÿä¹‹ç‹æ°å¥³ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤·å¾æ¯ï¼Œé‡è€³æ¯å¥³å¼Ÿä¹Ÿã€‚ ç»å…¬å­å…«äººï¼Œè€Œå¤ªå­ç”³ç”Ÿã€é‡è€³ã€å¤·å¾çš†æœ‰è³¢è¡Œã€‚ åŠå¾—é©ªå§¬ï¼Œä¹ƒé æ­¤ä¸‰å­ã€‚
In the twelfth year, Li Ji gave birth to Xi Qi. Xian Gong had thoughts of abolishing the crown prince, so he said: 'Quwo is my ancestral temple location, and Pu borders Qin while Qu borders the Di - I cannot let my various sons reside there, for I fear them.' Therefore he sent the crown prince Shen Sheng to reside at Quwo, Prince Chong Er at Pu, and Prince Yi Wu at Qu. Xian Gong resided at Jiang with Li Ji's son Xi Qi. The people of Jin thereby knew that the crown prince would not be established. The crown prince Shen Sheng's mother was Jiang of Qi, daughter of Duke Huan of Qi, but she died early. Chong Er's mother was a woman from the Di tribe. Yi Wu's mother was Chong Er's mother's younger sister. Xian Gong had eight sons, but only the crown prince Shen Sheng, Chong Er, and Yi Wu had worthy conduct. After obtaining Li Ji, he distanced these three sons. In the sixteenth year, Jin Xian Gong created two armies.

The duke led the upper army himself, while Crown Prince Shen Sheng led the lower army. Zhao Shu drove the chariot, Bi Wan served as right-hand man, and they attacked and extinguished Huo, extinguished Wei, and extinguished Geng. Upon returning, they walled Quwo for the crown prince, granted Zhao Shu Geng, and granted Bi Wan Wei, appointing them as ministers. Shi Kui said: 'The crown prince cannot be established. They divided his capital city, positioned him as a minister, first made it extreme for him, so how can he be established? It would be better to flee, so as not to let the crime reach him. To be like Wu Tai Bo, would that not also leave a good reputation?' The crown prince did not follow this advice. Bu Yan said: 'Bi Wan's descendants will surely be great. Wan means full, Wei means great name. To begin rewarding with this - Heaven is opening it. The Son of Heaven is called myriad people, feudal lords are called ten thousand people. Now commanding greatness, following the full number, their crowd will surely be great.' Initially, Bi Wan divined about taking office in Jin country and encountered the Tun hexagram with Bi. Xin Liao interpreted it, saying: 'Auspicious. Tun is solid, Bi enters - how can auspiciousness be greater? His descendants will surely flourish and prosper.'

In the seventeenth year, Jin Hou sent Crown Prince Shen Sheng to attack Dong Shan. Li Ke advised Xian Gong, saying: 'The crown prince serves the ancestral temple sacrifices and morning-evening offerings to the lord, so he is called the eldest son. When the lord travels, he guards; when there is guarding, he follows. Following is called stroking the army, guarding is called overseeing the country. Ancient was the system. To lead troops is to specialize in strategy; to swear the army is the lord and state government's planning. It is not the crown prince's matter. Troops are controlled by commands only, receiving commands then not awe-inspiring, specializing in commands then not filial. So the lord's proper successor cannot lead troops. The lord loses his official duties, leads troops without awe - what use is he?' The duke said: 'I have sons, but do not know who will be the crown prince.' Li Ke answered nothing and retired, then saw the crown prince. The crown prince said: 'Will I be abolished?' Li Ke said: 'Crown prince, strive! Teaching with military affairs, not sharing this fear, why be abolished? Moreover, fear not being filial, do not fear not being established. Cultivate yourself without blaming others, then avoid calamity.'

Xian Gong privately told Li Ji: 'I wish to abolish the crown prince and establish Xi Qi instead.' Li Ji wept and said: 'The crown prince's establishment has already been known by all feudal lords, and he has often led troops, with the hundred clans attaching to him. How can I, a lowly concubine, cause the lord to abolish the proper heir and establish the concubine-born? If the lord must do this, I will kill myself.' Li Ji pretended to praise the crown prince, but secretly sent people to slander and harm him, all while scheming to establish her own son. In the twenty-first year, Li Ji told the crown prince: 'The lord dreamed of seeing Jiang of Qi, so the crown prince should quickly sacrifice at Quwo and return blessing to the lord.' The crown prince then sacrificed to his mother Jiang of Qi at Quwo and offered his sacrificial meat to Xian Gong. Xian Gong was out hunting at the time and had placed the meat in the palace. Li Ji sent people to secretly put poison in the meat. After two days, Xian Gong returned from hunting and wished to eat the meat. Li Ji stopped him from the side, saying: 'The meat came from far away, so it should be tested.' They sacrificed to the ground and the ground swelled; gave it to the dog and the dog died; gave it to the servant and the servant died. Li Ji wept and said: 'How cruel the crown prince is! He wishes to kill his own father and replace him - moreover, what of others? The lord is old now, morning and evening a person, yet he cannot wait and wishes to kill him!' She told Xian Gong: 'The reason the crown prince acts this way is only because of me and Xi Qi. I beg to take my son and leave to another country. If we wait until we kill ourselves, it would be better than letting mother and son be fish and meat to the crown prince. I initially advised the lord not to abolish him, but hated it. Until now, I especially feel lost in this matter.' The crown prince heard this and fled to Xin City. Xian Gong was angry and executed the crown prince's tutor Du Yuan Kuan. Some told the crown prince: 'The one who made this poisoned meat is Li Ji. Why doesn't the crown prince personally explain and clarify it?' The crown prince said: 'My lord is old, without Li Ji he cannot sleep peacefully or eat sweetly. If I explain it, the lord will surely be angry with her.

In the twenty-second year, Xian Gong was angry that the two sons left without bidding farewell, believing they surely had rebellious intentions. Therefore he sent troops to attack Pu. In the twenty-third year, Xian Gong sent Jia Hua and others to attack Qu, which collapsed.

Yi Wu was about to flee to Di. Ji Rui said: 'This is not possible. Chong Er is already in Di, now if we go, Jin will surely shift troops to attack Di, and Di will fear Jin, bringing calamity upon us. It would be better to flee to Liang, for Liang is near Qin, and Qin is strong. Our lord's son will be able to seek to return after a hundred years.' They then fled to Liang. In the twenty-fifth year, Jin attacked Di, but Di attacked Jin at Nie Sang because of Chong Er, and Jin's troops dispersed and left. At this time, Jin was strong, controlling the west bank of the Yellow River with Qin as border, the north bordering Di, and east reaching within the He River. Li Ji's younger brother gave birth to Dao Zi. In summer of the twenty-sixth year, Duke Huan of Qi assembled the feudal lords at Kui Qiu. Jin Xian Gong was ill and set out to go but did not arrive, meeting Zhou's steward Kong. Steward Kong said: 'Duke Huan of Qi is increasingly arrogant, attending to distant strategy rather than virtue, the feudal lords are not at peace. Your younger brother should not attend, for there will be no harm to Jin.' Xian Gong was also ill and returned. His illness became serious, so he told Xun Xi: 'I establish Xi Qi as successor, but he is young, the various ministers will not submit, fearing disorder will arise. Can you establish him?' Xun Xi said: 'I can.' Xian Gong said: 'What will serve as proof?' He replied: 'To make the dead live again and the living not feel ashamed - that will serve as proof.' Thus he entrusted Xi Qi to Xun Xi. Xun Xi became chancellor and managed the state government.

In autumn of the ninth month, Xian Gong died. Li Ke and Pi Zheng wished to welcome Chong Er, using the followers of the three princes to make disorder, telling Xun Xi: 'Three resentments will rise, Qin and Jin will assist them. What will you do?' Xun Xi said: 'I cannot betray my previous lord's words.' In the tenth month, Li Ke killed Xi Qi at the mourning place, for Xian Gong had not yet been buried. Xun Xi was about to die for this, but some said it would be better to establish Xi Qi's younger brother Dao Zi and assist him. Xun Xi established Dao Zi and buried Xian Gong. In the eleventh month, Li Ke assassinated Dao Zi at court, and Xun Xi died for him. The gentleman said: 'The Shi says: "A white jade's flaw can still be polished, but a word's flaw cannot be remedied." This refers to Xun Xi - he did not betray his words.' Initially, Xian Gong was about to attack Li Rong and divined, receiving "teeth will bring calamity." But he conquered Li Rong and obtained Li Ji, whom he loved, and this finally brought disorder to Jin.

Li Ke and others had already killed Xi Qi and Dao Zi, and sent people to welcome Prince Chong Er from Di, wishing to establish him. Chong Er declined, saying: 'Bearing my father's command to flee, I could not obtain permission to serve at his mourning when my father died. How dare Chong Er enter? The ministers should establish another son instead.' They returned and reported to Li Ke, who sent people to welcome Yi Wu from Liang. Hui Gong, because Chong Er was outside, feared Li Ke would make trouble, so granted Li Ke death. He told him: 'Without Li Zi I could not have been established. Although, you also killed two lords and one minister - to serve as your lord's son would be difficult indeed.' Li Ke answered: 'Not having someone to abolish, how could the lord rise? If wishing to punish him, is there no words? But then to speak this! The minister has heard the command.' Thus he prostrated himself on his sword and died. Then Pi Zheng, who had gone to thank Qin, had not yet returned, so he did not reach the calamity.

Jin's lord reburied the respectful crown prince Shen Sheng. In autumn, Hu Tu went to the lower capital and met Shen Sheng, who rode with him and told him: 'Yi Wu has no ritual, I obtained permission from the emperor to give Jin to Qin, and Qin will sacrifice to me.' Hu Tu answered: 'I have heard that spirits do not eat from those not of their clan - the lord's sacrifice may be cut off. The lord should plan for it.' Shen Sheng said: 'Yes, I will again request from the emperor. After ten days, there will be a shaman who sees me at the west side of Xin City.' They promised it, then he did not appear. When the time came, he went again and appeared, telling Shen Sheng: 'The emperor has permitted punishment of the guilty, decaying at Han.' The child then prophesied: 'The respectful crown prince has been reburied, after fourteen years Jin will not prosper, but prosperity will come from the elder brother.'

Pi Zheng, having gone to Qin, heard that Li Ke had been executed, so he persuaded Qin's Mu Gong: 'Lu Sheng, Xi Cheng, Ji Rui truly do not follow. Qin's Mu Gong agreed and sent people to return and report to Jin, heavily bribing the three men. The three men said: 'The bribes are heavy, words sweet - this must be Pi Zheng selling us to Qin.' Thus they killed Pi Zheng and Li Ke's followers, seven chariot ministers. Pi Zheng's son Bao fled to Qin and spoke of attacking Jin, but Mu Gong did not listen.

Hui Gong's establishment betrayed Qin's land and Li Ke, executed seven chariot ministers, so the people of the country did not attach to him. In the second year, Zhou sent Zhao Gong Guo to perform the ritual for Jin's Hui Gong, but Hui Gong was arrogant in the ritual, so Zhao Gong criticized him.

In the fourth year, Jin suffered famine and begged to buy grain from Qin. Mu Gong asked Bai Li Xi, who said: 'Heavenly calamities circulate, countries have them alternately. To save calamity and relieve neighbors is the way of the state. Give it to them.' Pi Zheng's son Bao said: 'Attack them.' Mu Gong said: 'Their lord is evil, but what crime have their people committed?'

He finally gave them grain, from Yong to Jiang. In the fifth year, Qin suffered famine and requested to buy grain from Jin. Jin's lord plotted it, and Qing Zheng said: 'Previously, with Qin's help we were established, but then we betrayed their land agreement. When Jin suffered famine, Qin lent us grain; now when Qin suffers famine, should we refuse to sell them grain? But why plot it?' Guo She said: 'Previously heaven granted Jin to Qin, but Qin did not know to take it and lent us grain instead. Now heaven grants Qin to Jin - can Jin go against heaven?' Hui Gong followed Guo She's plan, did not give Qin grain, but sent troops to moreover attack Qin. Qin was greatly angered and also sent troops to attack Jin.

å…­å¹´æ˜¥ï¼Œç§¦ç¹†å…¬å°‡å…µä¼æ™‰ã€‚ æ™‰æƒ å…¬è¬‚æ…¶é„­æ›°ï¼šã€Œç§¦å¸«æ·±çŸ£ï¼ŒæŸ°ä½•ï¼Ÿã€ é„­æ›°ï¼šã€Œç§¦å…§å›ï¼Œå›å€å…¶è³‚ï¼› æ™‰é¥‘ç§¦è¼¸ç²Ÿï¼Œç§¦é¥‘è€Œæ™‰å€ä¹‹ï¼Œä¹ƒæ¬²å› å…¶é¥‘ä¼ä¹‹ï¼šå…¶æ·±ä¸äº¦å®œä¹ï¼ã€ æ™‰åœå¾¡å³ï¼Œæ…¶é„­çš†å‰ã€‚ å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œé„­ä¸å­«ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒæ›´ä»¤æ­¥é™½å¾¡æˆï¼Œå®¶ä»†å¾’ç‚ºå³ï¼Œé€²å…µã€‚ ä¹æœˆå£¬æˆŒï¼Œç§¦ç¹†å…¬ã€æ™‰æƒ å…¬åˆæˆ°éŸ“åŸã€‚ æƒ å…¬é¦¬é¨ºä¸è¡Œï¼Œç§¦å…µè‡³ï¼Œå…¬çª˜ï¼Œå¬æ…¶é„­ç‚ºå¾¡ã€‚ é„­æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸ç”¨åœï¼Œæ•—ä¸äº¦ç•¶ä¹ï¼ã€ é‚å»ã€‚ æ›´ä»¤æ¢ç¹‡é¡å¾¡ï¼Œè™¢å°„ç‚ºå³ï¼Œè¼…ç§¦ç¹†å…¬ã€‚ ç¹†å…¬å£¯å£«å†’æ•—æ™‰è»ï¼Œæ™‰è»æ•—ï¼Œé‚å¤±ç§¦ç¹†å…¬ï¼Œåç²æ™‰å…¬ä»¥æ­¸ã€‚ ç§¦å°‡ä»¥ç¥€ä¸Šå¸ã€‚ æ™‰å›å§Šç‚ºç¹†å…¬å¤«äººï¼Œè¡°ç»–æ¶•æ³£ã€‚ å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾—æ™‰ä¾¯å°‡ä»¥ç‚ºæ¨‚ï¼Œä»Šä¹ƒå¦‚æ­¤ã€‚ ä¸”å¾èç®•å­è¦‹å”å”ä¹‹åˆå°ï¼Œæ›°ã€å…¶å¾Œå¿…ç•¶å¤§çŸ£ã€ï¼Œæ™‰åº¸å¯æ»…ä¹ï¼ã€ ä¹ƒèˆ‡æ™‰ä¾¯ç›Ÿç‹åŸè€Œè¨±ä¹‹æ­¸ã€‚ æ™‰ä¾¯äº¦ä½¿å‘‚çœç­‰å ±åœ‹äººæ›°ï¼šã€Œå­¤é›–å¾—æ­¸ï¼Œæ¯‹é¢ç›®è¦‹ç¤¾ç¨·ï¼Œåœæ—¥ç«‹å­åœ‰ã€‚ã€ æ™‰äººèä¹‹ï¼Œçš†å“­ã€‚ ç§¦ç¹†å…¬å•å‘‚çœï¼šã€Œæ™‰åœ‹å’Œä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸å’Œã€‚ å°äººæ‡¼å¤±å›äº¡è¦ªï¼Œä¸æ†šç«‹å­åœ‰ï¼Œæ›°ã€å¿…å ±è®ï¼Œå¯§äº‹æˆã€ç‹„ã€ã€‚ å…¶å›å­å‰‡æ„›å›è€ŒçŸ¥ç½ªï¼Œä»¥å¾…ç§¦å‘½ï¼Œæ›°ã€å¿…å ±å¾·ã€ã€‚ æœ‰æ­¤äºŒæ•…ï¼Œä¸å’Œã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ç§¦ç¹†å…¬æ›´èˆæ™‰æƒ å…¬ï¼Œé¤½ä¹‹ä¸ƒç‰¢ã€‚ åä¸€æœˆï¼Œæ­¸æ™‰ä¾¯ã€‚ æ™‰ä¾¯è‡³åœ‹ï¼Œèª…æ…¶é„­ï¼Œä¿®æ”¿æ•™ã€‚ è¬€æ›°ï¼šã€Œé‡è€³åœ¨å¤–ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯å¤šåˆ©å…§ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ¬²ä½¿äººæ®ºé‡è€³æ–¼ç‹„ã€‚ é‡è€³èä¹‹ï¼Œå¦‚é½Šã€‚
In spring of the sixth year, Qin's Mu Gong led troops to attack Jin. Jin's Hui Gong told Qing Zheng: 'Qin's troops have gone deep - what should we do?' Zheng said: 'Qin helped establish the lord, but the lord betrayed their bribe; when Jin suffered famine Qin transported grain, but when Qin suffers famine Jin betrays them, moreover wishing to take advantage of their famine to attack them. Their deep penetration is only fitting.' Jin divined the driver and assistant, and Qing Zheng were all auspicious. The duke said: 'Zheng is disrespectful.' Thus he changed to command Bu Yang to drive and Jia Pu Tu as assistant, advancing troops. In the ninth month, on Wu Xu, Qin's Mu Gong and Jin's Hui Gong battled at Han Yuan. Hui Gong's horse stumbled and could not advance, Qin's troops arrived, and he was in distress, so he summoned Qing Zheng to drive. Zheng said: 'Without divination, defeat would be fitting anyway.' Thus he left. He changed to command Liang You Mi to drive and Guo She as assistant, attacking Qin's Mu Gong. Mu Gong's brave warriors took the risk and defeated Jin's army, so Jin's army was defeated, but they lost Qin's Mu Gong and instead captured and returned with Jin's duke. Qin wished to sacrifice to Shangdi. Jin's lord's elder sister was Mu Gong's wife, who wailed in mourning clothes. The duke said: 'I obtained Jin's duke to make him entertainment, but now it is like this. Moreover I have heard Ji Zi say when Tang Shu was first enfeoffed: "His descendants will surely be great." How can Jin be extinguished?' Thus he made an alliance with Jin's duke at Wang City and permitted him to return. Jin's duke also sent Lu Sheng and others to report to the country's people: 'I, though obtaining return, have no face to see the state altars, so divine a day to establish Zi Yu.' Jin's people heard it and all cried. Qin's Mu Gong asked Lu Sheng: 'Is Jin peaceful?' He answered: 'Not peaceful. The small people fear losing their lord and perishing relatives, do not dare to establish Zi Yu, saying "we must repay enmity, would rather serve Rong or Di." Their gentlemen love their lord and know their crime, waiting for Qin's command, saying "we must repay virtue." There are these two reasons, so not peaceful.' Thus Qin's Mu Gong changed to lodge Jin's Hui Gong and presented him seven cattle. In the eleventh month, he returned Jin's duke. Jin's duke arrived in the country, executed Qing Zheng, and cultivated government and teachings. He plotted: 'Chong Er is outside, many feudal lords profit by welcoming him.'

å…«å¹´ï¼Œä½¿å¤ªå­åœ‰è³ªç§¦ã€‚ åˆï¼Œæƒ å…¬äº¡åœ¨æ¢ï¼Œæ¢ä¼¯ä»¥å…¶å¥³å¦»ä¹‹ï¼Œç”Ÿä¸€ç”·ä¸€å¥³ã€‚ æ¢ä¼¯åœä¹‹ï¼Œç”·ç‚ºäººè‡£ï¼Œå¥³ç‚ºäººå¦¾ï¼Œæ•…åç”·ç‚ºåœ‰ï¼Œå¥³ç‚ºå¦¾ã€‚

So he named the son Yu and the daughter Concubine. In the tenth year, Qin extinguished Liang. Liang's lord loved great works, governing the city moat, so the people were exhausted and resented, their multitude several times alarmed themselves saying "Qin bandits have arrived," the people feared and confused, so Qin finally extinguished Liang. In the thirteenth year, Jin's Hui Gong was ill, with several sons internally. Crown Prince Yu said: 'My mother's family is in Liang, but Liang has now been extinguished by Qin. I am weak externally toward Qin and have no support internally in the country. If the lord does not rise, the various ministers will be light, and they will establish another prince.' In the fourteenth year, ninth month, Hui Gong died, and Crown Prince Yu ascended as Huai Gong. Zi Yu had fled, so Qin resented him and sought Prince Chong Er, wishing to welcome him. Zi Yu's establishment feared Qin's attack. Thus he commanded the country's various followers of Chong Er who had fled with him to set a period, those who did not arrive by the period would all have their families extinguished. Hu Tu's son Mao and Yan followed Chong Er in Qin and would not summon. Huai Gong was angered and imprisoned Hu Tu. From youth he loved scholars, at age seventeen having five worthy scholars: Zhao Shuai, Hu Yan Jiu Fan (his maternal uncle), Jia Tuo, Xian Zhen, Wei Wu Zi. From when Xian Gong was crown prince, Chong Er was already an adult. When Xian Gong ascended the throne, Chong Er was twenty-one. In Xian Gong's thirteenth year, because of Li Ji's influence, Chong Er was stationed at Pu city to guard against Qin. In Xian Gong's twenty-first year, Xian Gong killed Crown Prince Shen Sheng, Li Ji slandered Chong Er, who feared and without bidding farewell to Xian Gong guarded Pu city. Chong Er then fled to Di. Di was his mother's tribe. At this time Chong Er was forty-three. He was followed by these five scholars, and others not named numbered over several tens, arriving at Di. He resided in Di for five years until Jin's Xian Gong died, when Li Ke had already killed Xi Qi and Dao Zi, then sent people to welcome Chong Er, wishing to establish him. Chong Er feared the killing and firmly declined, not daring to enter. Soon after, Jin established his younger brother Yi Wu as Hui Gong. In Hui Gong's seventh year, fearing Chong Er, he sent the eunuch Lu Di and brave warriors wishing to kill Chong Er. Chong Er heard it and plotted with Zhao Shuai and others: 'Initially I fled to Di, not because it was useful to ally with, but because it was near and easy to pass through, so I rested my feet. I have rested long, firmly wishing to move to a great country. Duke Huan of Qi loves goodness, his will is in hegemony and receiving the feudal lords. Now I hear Guan Zhong and Xi Peng have died, so he also wishes to obtain worthy assistants. Why not go?'

He passed through Wei, but Wei's Wen Gong did not give him ritual. Now Chu is a great country and has treated you well - you should not decline, this is Heaven opening for you.' Thus he received guest ritual to see him. Cheng Wang treated Chong Er thickly, Chong Er very humble. Cheng Wang said: 'If you return to country, what will you report to me?' Chong Er said: 'Feathers, furs, teeth, horns, jade, silks - things the lord wang has in surplus, I do not know what to report.' The wang said: 'Although, what will you report to Bu Gu?' Chong Er said: 'If inevitably so, then with lord wang together with war chariots to assemble on plains and broad marshes, I beg to retreat wang three she.' Chu's general Zi Yu angered: 'Wang treated Jin's prince extremely thickly, now Chong Er speaks disrespectfully - please kill him.' Cheng Wang said: 'Jin's prince is worthy and distressed outside long, his followers are all state vessels - this is Heaven placed, how can we kill him? Moreover, his words - what can change them!'

Ping Gong first year, attacked Qi, Qi Ling Gong with battled Mi Xia, Qi army defeated fled. Yan Ying said: 'Lord also no courage, why not stop battle?' Then left. Jin pursued, surrounded Lin Zi, completely burned slaughtered its outer city. East to Jiao, south to Yi, Qi all walled defended, Jin then led troops returned.

Sixth year, Lu Xiang Gong courted Jin. Jin Luan Cheng had crime, fled Qi. Eighth year, Qi Zhuang Gong secretly sent Luan Cheng at Qu Wo, with troops followed him. Qi troops ascended Tai Xing, Luan Cheng from Qu Wo middle contrary, attacked entered Jiang. Jiang not prepared, Ping Gong wished suicide, Fan Xian Zi stopped Gong, with his followers attacked Cheng, Cheng defeated fled Qu Wo. Qu Wo attacked Cheng, Cheng died, extinguished Luan clan ancestor. Cheng, Luan Shu grandson. His entered Jiang, with Wei clan plotted. Qi Zhuang Gong heard Cheng defeated, returned, took Jin Chao Ge left, repaid Lin Zi campaign.

Tenth year, Qi Cui Zhu assassinated his lord Zhuang Gong. Jin because Qi disorder, attacked defeated Qi at Gao Tang left, repaid Tai Xing campaign.

Fourteenth year, Wu Yan Ling Ji Zi came envoy, with Zhao Wen Zi, Han Xuan Zi, Wei Xian Zi spoke, said: 'Jin country government, finally return this three families.'

Nineteenth year, Qi sent Yan Ying like Jin, with Shu Xiang spoke. Shu Xiang said: 'Jin, last generation. Gong thick collected for towers pools not relieve government, government in private gates, its able long?' Yan Zi approved it.

Ninth year, Lu Ji clan drove their lord Zhao Gong, Zhao Gong resided Gan Hou. Eleventh year, Wei Song sent envoys requested Jin accept Lu lord. Ji Ping Zi private bribed Fan Xian Zi, Xian Zi received it, told Jin lord said: 'Ji clan no crime.' Not succeed enter Lu lord.

Twelfth year, Jin ancestral family Qi Xi grandson, Shu Xiang son, mutually disliked at lord. Six ministers wished weak gong chamber, with law completely extinguished their clan. Divided their cities as ten counties, each commanded their son as grand master. Jin increasingly weak, six ministers all great.

Fifteenth year, Zhao Meng sent Han Dan grand master Wu, not believed, wished kill Wu, Wu with Zhong Xing Yin, Fan Ji She relatives attacked Zhao Meng, Meng fled protected Jin Yang. Ding Gong surrounded Jin Yang. Xun Yue, Han Bu Xin, Wei Chi with Fan Zhong Xing, Zhong Xing for enemy, shifted troops attacked Fan Zhong Xing. Fan Zhong Xing contrary, Jin lord attacked them, defeated Fan Zhong Xing. Fan Zhong Xing walked Chao Ge, protected it. Han Wei for Zhao Meng apologized Jin lord, pardoned Zhao Meng, restored position. Twenty-second year, Jin defeated Fan Zhong Xing clan, two sons fled Qi.

Chu Gong seventeenth year, Zhi Bo with Zhao Han Wei together divided Fan Zhong Xing land as cities. Chu Gong angered, informed Qi Lu, wished with attack four ministers. Four ministers feared, contrary attacked Chu Gong. Chu Gong fled Qi, road died. So Zhi Bo established Zhao Gong great grandson Jiao as Jin lord, this was Ai Gong.

Ai Gong great grandfather Yong, Jin Zhao Gong young son, numbered Dai Zi. Dai Zi gave birth Ji. Ji good Zhi Bo, early died, so Zhi Bo wished completely unite Jin, not dared, established Ji son Jiao as lord. At this time, Jin country government all decided Zhi Bo, Jin Ai Gong not able have control. Zhi Bo then possessed Fan Zhong Xing land, most strong.

Twenty-seventh year, Lie Gong died, son Xiao Gong Ni established. Xiao Gong ninth year, Wei Wu Hou initial established, attacked Han Dan, not conquer left. Seventeenth year, Xiao Gong died, son Jing Gong Ju Jiu established. This year, Qi Wei Wang first year.

Jing Gong second year, Wei Wu Hou, Han Ai Hou, Zhao Jing Hou extinguished Jin after divided its land three ways. Jing Gong moved as commoner, Jin cut off not sacrifice.

Grand Historian said: Jin Wen Gong, ancient called enlightened lord, perished resided outside nineteen years, to extremely distressed, and ascended position carried reward, still forgot Jie Zi Tui, moreover arrogant lord? Ling Gong already assassinated, its after Cheng Jing brought strict, to Li greatly harsh, grand masters feared executed, calamity made. Dao Gong after day declined, six ministers monopolized power.
